frame.name: Location_of_light
frame.definition:
<def-root>A perceptible <fen>Figure</fen> shows up against a <fen>Ground</fen> location due to <fen>Light</fen> shining on/from it, its salience possibly dependent on a <fen>Cause_of_shine</fen>.
<ex><fex name="Fig">The grass</fex> <t>glistened</t> <fex name="Shine">with dew</fex>.</ex> <ex>Still <t>glowing</t> <fex name="Shine">from the forge</fex>...</ex> <ex><fex name="Fig">The oily mud</fex> <t>gleamed</t> <fex name="Shine">wetly</fex> <fex name="Grnd">under his feet</fex>.</ex> <ex><fex name="Fig">Something</fex> was <t>shimmering</t> <fex name="Grnd">on the shore</fex>.</ex> <ex><fex name="Fig">The quartz</fex> <t>glowed</t> <fex name="Lit">with a fitful, internal light</fex>.</ex> <ex><fex name="Fig">The walls</fex> <t>glowed</t> <fex name="Grnd">in the sun</fex>.</ex> <ex></ex>
Note that in this last example, the PP 'in the sun' is both the <fen>Ground</fen> on the primary FE layer and <fen>Light</fen> on the secondary layer.
<ex></ex> This frame is similar to the frame Light_movement. In both, there is a very consistent metaphorical conception of emotions as shining in eyes or forth from eyes, including the associated pattern of eyes shining with an emotion. The sense in such cases is that the eyes (or the muscles and features around the eyes) are in such a configuration as to saliently convey the emotion. Such sentences should be tagged with the metaphor tag to differentiate them from literal sentences like "His eyes glistened with tears." </def-root>

FE.name: Degree
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Degree</fen> to which the <fen>Light</fen> is emitted, usually indicating the brightness.</def-root>

FE.name: Depictive
FE.definition: <def-root>The state of a focal participant during the emission of <fen>Light</fen> . <ex>The moonlight <t>shone</t> <fex name="Dep">cold</fex> over the Scottish moor.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Manner
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Manner</fen> of <fen>Light</fen> emission. <ex>In the dim light the gold and strong colours <t>glittered</t> and glowed <fex name="Manr">intensely</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Figure
FE.definition: <def-root>The percept which is perceived at a certain <fen>Ground</fen> location. <ex><fex name="Fig">Candlelight</fex> <t>sparkled</t> on the silverware.</ex><ex><fex name="Fig">Her face</fex> <t>glistened</t> with sweat.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Ground
FE.definition: <def-root>The location of the phenomenon.<ex>Hot coals <t>glowed</t> <fex name="Grnd">behind the fire grate</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Result
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Result</fen> of the emission of the <fen>Light</fen> . <ex>The screen <t>glowed</t> <fex name="Result">into life</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Cause_of_shine
FE.definition: <def-root>This is the cause of the shininess of the phenomenon, generally introduced by 'with'.<ex>Her face <t>glistened</t> <fex name="Shine">with sweat</fex>.</ex><ex>His eyes <t>gleamed</t> <fex name="Shine">with amusement</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Light
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Light</fen> which is emitted. In this frame, it is usually incorporated in verbs and adjectives, and is the denotation of many of the nouns. <ex>The fire <fex name="Lit"><t>glowed</t></fex>.</ex> <ex>The <fex name="Light"><t>glint</t></fex> of gold made me blind with greed.</ex>
Occasionally this FE shows up as a full argument:<ex>The chamber <fex name="Lit"><t>glowed</t></fex> <fex name="Lit">with brilliant light</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Duration
FE.definition:
<def-root>The period for which the <fen>Figure</fen> shows up against the <fen>Ground</fen> due to <fen>Light</fen> falling on it.
<ex><fex name="Duration">For a few minutes</fex> the walls <t>glowed</t> in the sun</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Place
FE.definition:
<def-root>The spatial setting in which the <fen>Figure</fen> shows up against a <fen>Ground</fen> location.
<ex><fex name="Place">Outside</fex> something was <t>shimmering</t> on the shore.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Time
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Figure</fen> is observed against the <fen>Ground</fen> location due to <fen>Light</fen> shining on it.
<ex><fex name="Time">In the morning</fex> the grass <t>glistened</t> with dew</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: glow.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: give out steady light without flame.

lexUnit.name: glisten.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: shine or sparkle (as on something wet or moist)

lexUnit.name: glimmer.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: shine faintly with a wavering light.

lexUnit.name: twinkle.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: shine with a gleam that changes constantly from bright to faint.

lexUnit.name: shimmer.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: shine with a soft tremulous light.

lexUnit.name: glint.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: give out or reflect small flashes of light.

lexUnit.name: flash.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: shine or cause to shine in a bright but brief, sudden, or intermittent way.

lexUnit.name: sparkle.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: shine brightly with flashes of light.

lexUnit.name: gleam.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: shine brightly, especially with reflected light.

lexUnit.name: glitter.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: shine with a bright, shimmering reflected light.

lexUnit.name: shine.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: give out a bright light; glow with reflected light.

lexUnit.name: flicker.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: shine or burn unsteadily and fitfully.

lexUnit.name: coruscate.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: to flash or sparkle.

lexUnit.name: flame.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: give off flames.

lexUnit.name: scintillate.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: emit flashes of light; sparkle.

lexUnit.name: flare.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: burn, shine, or be revealed with a sudden intensity.

lexUnit.name: glint.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a small flash of light, especially a reflected one.

lexUnit.name: gleam.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a faint or brief light.

lexUnit.name: glimmer.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a faint or wavering light.

lexUnit.name: flicker.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an instance of flickering.

lexUnit.name: coruscation.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: flash or sparkle.

lexUnit.name: scintillation.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a flash of light.

lexUnit.name: glitter.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a bright, shimmering reflected light.

lexUnit.name: glow.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a steady radiance of light or heat.

lexUnit.name: twinkle.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a twinkling sparkle or gleam.

lexUnit.name: flashing.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: giving off light in bright, sudden and/or intermittent bursts.

lexUnit.name: gleaming.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: shining brightly, especially with reflected light.

lexUnit.name: glittering.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: reflecting or shining small quantities of individual, separate points of light.

lexUnit.name: flash.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a sudden brief burst of bright light.

lexUnit.name: glistening.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: shining or sparkling, as on something wet.

lexUnit.name: shining.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: reflecting light brightly.

lexUnit.name: shine.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a quality of brightness, especially through reflecting light.

lexUnit.name: sheen.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a soft lustre on a surface.

lexUnit.name: lustre.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a gentle sheen or soft glow.

lexUnit.name: lambent.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: glowing or flickering with a soft radiance.

lexUnit.name: refulgent.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: shining very brightly.

lexUnit.name: lambency.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a glow or soft radiant flicker

lexUnit.name: refulgence.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a very bright shine.

lexUnit.name: bright.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: giving out much light, or filled with light.

lexUnit.name: brilliant.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: very bright or vivid.

lexUnit.name: glossy.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: shiny and smooth.

lexUnit.name: shiny.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: reflecting light because very smooth, clean, or polished.

lexUnit.name: glister.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: sparkle; glitter.

lexUnit.name: glister.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a sparkle.

lexUnit.name: light.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the natural agent that stimulates sight and makes things visible; electromagnetic radiation from about 390 to 740 nm in wavelength.
